text: hi my name is Dan Blaine er I'm a
Solutions Architect with AWS and I'm
here to talk to you today about the
developer tools announcements that we
announced at arraignment first update is
the a nebulous toolkit for PyCharm
PyCharm is a python ide produced by
JetBrains and the toolkit is a plug-in
for that ide the plugin integrates with
the nus service application models or
sam and the sam provides an easy way for
defining all the components in a service
app and as an extension of
CloudFormation
the plugin integrates with Sam to allow
you to launch new projects using Sam
templates it also integrates with Sam to
run and debug service apps right on your
local developer workstation it provides
a step through debugger to make
debugging very easy within the plug-in
within the IDE you can deploy your
lambda functions and your same
applications right into the API service
without having to use the CLI and from
within the IDE you can also invoke your
lambda functions remotely in the service
the next announcement is continuous
delivery support for Fargate and for ECS
now you can do blue/green deployments
into ECS using code deploy the ECS
service sets up code deploy for you
whenever you choose the blue-green
deployment type for your service your
service must be behind in alb for this
to work you can trigger the blue-green
deployments whenever you update your ECS
service using either the console the CLI
or the SDK and you also have access to
code deployed directly to kick off a
deployment
directly we also announce that the
elastic container registry or ECR is a
source provider for code pipeline this
means that whenever you update deploy an
updated container into the registry it
kicks off a pipeline update so that you
can do a Bluegreen deployment there's a
great tutorial on this in the ECS
documentation we provide a link in the
slides another big announcement is that
lambda now supports Ruby this has been a
long requested feature by developers Lam
and supports Ruby 2.5 and you can write
your Ruby scripts your Ruby functions
directly in the lambda editor right in
the console like you would if you were
building Python you can also test your
Ruby functions locally using the service
application model Ruby support flam DES
is available in all regions where lambda
is is available the next big
announcement is lambda layers
with lambda layers you can package all
of your code data and other dependencies
for your lambda functions without having
to deploy them with each function so now
you can centrally manage all of your
common dependencies instead of doing
duplicate packaging you can deploy your
layers separately than your functions
and manage deployment of your layers
separately from your lambda functions so
now for example if you're building your
lambda functions in Java and you use a
lot of open source jars you don't need
to package all those jars into every
single lambda function deployment you
can bundle those as a separate layer and
simply refer to those from your lambda
function lambdas heavily used by data
scientists and so AWS is providing
lambda optimized versions of the numpy
and scifi Python libraries as a layer so
now if you're building Python based data
science lambda functions you can simply
set up your lambda function to use those
layers and now you don't have to worry
about packaging those libraries yourself
the service application model or Sam
also supports layers so you can do local
testing of your layer based lambda
functions every function can use up to
five different layers as well so you can
further manage the granularity of all of
your layers and you can reference layers
cross account as well so you can provide
your code dependencies on one account
and reference them from functions in
whatever other accounts to use an update
a layer you simply update the function
the configuration of your lambda
function the next update is lambda
custom runtimes now you can provide
support for virtually any programming
language regardless of whether or not
the land of function the language
service supports in itself there are
some caveats the language must be able
to run on Amazon Linux
when you build a custom runtime we
provide you with an ami and that ami
includes the AWS SDK for JavaScript as
well as the SDK for Python if you have
any other dependencies you must provide
them yourself in the deployment bundle
when you build your own time you can
either provide it pet and package it up
with your lambda function or you can
build it as a layer so that multiple
functions can use your custom runtime a
runtime is a either custom binary or
even a shell script that handles
execution of your lambda functions and
it has to perform a certain several
certain functions number one it has to
initialize the runtime and any lambda
functions
that's associated with and it has to
pull the lamb to service for new
invocation events to run when it
receives a new event it creates context
and then invokes the function handler to
execute the function code it handles any
responses or errors from your lambda
function and ships those back to the
lambda service and that finally performs
any cleanup necessary your custom
runtime interacts with the land of
service through an HD based HTTP based
runtime interface that runtime interface
provides several functions including the
ability to pull for new invocation
events and for notifying the lander
service of function responses and errors
several third-party partners are
building their own custom runtimes to
provide support for languages such as
PHP COBOL Erlang and some others and
finally it reinvent we announced land
and support for application load
balancers now you don't need to build
out an API using API gateway if you want
to build a lambda based web application
you can simply create an application
little balancer and hang your lambda
functions off of that load balancer and
alb can route traffic to one or more
lambda functions and you can use content
routing rules to determine which
functions handle which traffic this
feature is available in all commercial
regions and gokon West so those are all
the updates I have for you today give
those a try and if you have any
questions feel free to contact your
Solutions Architect
or your account team thanks
